title: How to prove that 2n + 1 ≤ 2n for n≥ 3. [5] - Quora

response.answer_text: By induction, of course! Suppose we know that 2n+1≤2n2n+1≤2n; we wish to show that it follows 2(n+1)+1≤2(n+1)2(n+1)+1≤2(n+1). Indeed, we have 2(n+1)+1=2n+1+2≤2n+2=2(n+1)2(n+1)+1=2n+1+2≤2n+2=2(n+1) Well done! Now we have just to drop in the base case, that is n=3n=3. OK, 2n+1=2⋅3+1=72n+1=2⋅3+1=7 and 2n=2⋅3=62n=2⋅3=6. So you’re reduced to prove that 7≤67≤6. Once you’ve done it you earn the 5 marks.
In [3,infin)…2n + 1 has to be larger than 2n because 2n + 1 is one bigger than 2n. You show 2n + 1 <= 2n which I don’t think is possible.
